questions.text: The final conditioning of the spermatozoa in the female reproductive tract takes place in the  _______.
questions.solution:
The final conditioning of the spermatozoa in the female reproductive tract is called capacitation and it occurs in the uterine tube.

It is a period of conditioning (adaptation of sperm in the female reproductive tract), which lasts approximately 7 hours.

Fertilization involves two steps: 

1) Capacitation 

  • Capacitation occurs in the uterine tube and involves epithelial interactions between the sperm and the mucosal surface of the tube.
  • During capacitation, the glycoprotein coat and seminal plasma proteins are removed.
  • Only capacitated sperms can pass through the corona cells and undergo the acrosomal reaction.

2) Acrosomal reaction 

  • It occurs after binding to zona pellucida, induced by zona proteins. 
  • This includes the release of enzymes required to penetrate the zona pellucida. 
  • Ca2+ plays an important role.

Phases can be divided as follows: 

  • Phase 1: Penetration of the corona radiata
  • Phase 2: Penetration of the zona pellucida
  • Phase 3: Fusion of the oocyte and sperm cell membranes

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used by obstetricians:
questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigleys forceps, which is an outlet forceps. It is used to provide traction force and can also be used in caesarean sections.

The instrument is light, about a third of the weight of an ordinary long-curved forceps. The instrument is short which is due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve.

Other options:

Kielland forceps:

It is a long almost straight (very slight pelvic curve) obstetric forceps without any axis-traction device. It has got a sliding lock which facilitates correction of asynclitism of the head. One small knob on each blade is directed towards the occiput.

Pipers forceps:

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Tucker Mclane forceps:

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text:
A primigravida whose blood group is B negative is being investigated for signs of fetal anemia at 35 weeks of gestation. On fetal MCA doppler, peak systolic velocity is 1.7 MoM, with a hematocrit of 40 %. What is the next step?

MCA - Middle cerebral artery

MoM - Multiples of median

choices.text: Deliver at 35 completed weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The next step is to deliver at 35 completed weeks of gestation.

In this scenario of an Rh-ve pregnancy at 35 weeks of gestation, where the peak systolic velocity of MCA is 1.7 MoM (>1.5 MoM), delivery at >/=34 completed weeks is recommended. 

Fetal middle cerebral artery Doppler measurements of peak systolic velocity(PSV) are the recommended test for the detection of fetal anemia. In the anemic fetus, blood is shunted preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxy­genation. As a result, the velocity rises because of increased cardiac out­put and decreased blood viscosity.  

If the PSV is between 1.0 and 1.5 MoM and the slope is rising and approaching 1.5 MoM, fetal surveillance is increased to weekly Doppler examination. If the MCA peak systolic velocity > 1.5 MoM and the gestational age is <34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered and followed by fetal transfu­sion if needed. If the gestation age is >/=34 weeks, delivery is considered.

The algorithm for the management of Rh-ve pregnancy is given below:

questions.text: A 26-year-old P1L1  woman is diagnosed with abnormal uterine bleeding. Considering she has not completed her family, which of these treatment methods will be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Mirena will be the most appropriate method of treatment in a young woman with AUB (desirous of preserving fertility) as the rest of the options are ablative procedures.

Ablative procedures are safe, effective with less morbidity, and quicker recovery and the method destroys 2-3 mm of the myometrium. But, fertility is not possible following ablative procedures.

 

Advantages of Mirena IUCD over ablative techniques:

  • Low cost
  • OPD procedure: No hospitalization
  • Preservation of fertility after its removal

Other options:

NovaSure (impedance-controlled endometrial ablation) is the latest and most safe procedure, taking just 90 sec. It uses bipolar radiofrequency and vaporizes endometrium up to myometrium.

Vesta system. This system uses a single-use multi-electrode intrauterine balloon to ablate the endometrium.

questions.text: Which among the following is the characteristic complication associated with chorionic villus sampling?
questions.solution:
Limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular hypogenesis are complications associated with chorionic villus sampling.

The best time to perform Chorionic villous sampling is 11-13 weeks.

Chorionic villus sampling

Study material

Chorionic villi from trophoblastic cells

Time

10-13 week (Transcervically)

10 weeks-term (Transabdominally)

Indications

To detect cytogenetic, biochemical, chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome.
Complications

Abortion (CVS> Amniocentesis)

Limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular defects (when done before 10 weeks )

Not suitable for detection of Neural tube defects.

Cord-vessel bleeding, fetal maternal bleeding, and fetal bradycardia are complications associated with fetal blood sampling.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh two days after vaginal delivery. Which among the following nerve injury causes her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.

The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament.

Other options-

Option A- The peroneal nerve can get compressed under the flexed knee during prolonged lithotomy positioning during labor. It can also occur when the patient's knees are resting against a firm surface like the hospital bed rails or stirrups during labor.

Options B and C- The iliohypogastric nerve and ilioinguinal nerve are most commonly injured during cesarean section.

questions.text: A 2nd degree perineal tear involves :

choices.text: Internal anal sphincter + External anal sphincter

questions.solution:
A 2nd-degree perineal tear involves the perineal muscles i.e, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal muscles.

Other options :

Any involvement of the rectal mucosa is categorised as a 4th-degree tear. (a,c)

Internal and external anal sphincter involvement is categorised as 3c, 3rd-degree perineal tear (d).

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with an atrial septal defect presents for safe confinement. Which among the following is a predictor of cardiac complications in a pregnant woman with heart disease?
questions.solution:
Prior heart failure is a predictor of cardiac complications in a pregnant woman with heart disease.

Predictors of cardiac complications include:

  • Prior heart failure, transient ischemic attack, arrhythmia or stroke
  • Baseline NYHA class III or IV or cyanosis
  • Left sided obstruction defined as a mitral valve area < 2 cm2, aortic valve area < 1.5 cm2, or peak left ventricular outflow tract gradient > 30 mmHg
  • Ejection fraction < 40%

 The risk of pulmonary edema, sustained arrhythmia, stroke, or cardiac arrest was substantially elevated with one of these factors and even more so with two or more.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is the Doyen retractor. It is used to pull back the soft tissues and widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

Simon retractor:

Simon vaginal retractor used to retract vaginal walls during examination and vaginal procedures.

Balfour retractor:

questions.solution:
The image shows uterine curette with sharp and blunt ends.

It is not used in uterine length measurements.

questions.text: The obstetric grip performed in the picture is used to detect ______.

choices.text: The fetal pole occupying the fundus

questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is the Pelvic grip (Leopold's fourth grip) and it is used to detect the degree of descent.

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers):

Leopold Grip Importance
First Fundal To know which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.
Second Lateral/Umbilical To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlick 

To know presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis
Fourth  Pelvic

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head

The four grips of Leopold:

questions.text: The best parameter for estimation of fetal age by USG in 2nd trimester is ______.
questions.solution:
Biparietal diameter (BPD) is the best parameter for the estimation of fetal age by USG in the 2nd trimester. Accuracy varies from 7 to 10 days. 

BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner edge of the skull in the far field. The best parameters for the estimation of fetal age are- 

Trimester

Parameter

First

Crown-rump length (CRL)

Second

Biparietal diameter (BPD)

Third

Femur length

Overall

Crown-rump length (CRL)

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. The size of the uterus corresponds to the period of amenorrhea. On examination, the external os is closed. USG shows a well-formed gestational sac with fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of threatened abortion.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows a well-formed gestation ring indicating a healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Treatment involves bed rest, analgesics to relieve pain, and progesterone.

Related Pearl: Clinical classification of Spontaneous Abortion

Clinical type Description/ Clinical picture USG/ Investigations
Threatened 

Bloody vaginal discharge or bleeding

Closed cervical os

Gestational sac/ pseudo-gestational sac present

Fetal cardiac activity present
Inevitable 

Gush of vaginal fluid or bleeding

Cramping or fever

Dilated cervical os

Gross rupture of membranes

Low lying sac

Oligohydramnios
Incomplete 

Vaginal bleeding

Partial or complete placental separation

Dilated cervical os

Retained products of conception
Complete 

Heavy vaginal bleeding with cramps

Complete placental separation with the passage of tissue or a fetus 

Closed cervical os

Minimally thickened endometrium

Gestational sac absent
Missed /early pregnancy failure or loss

Dead products of conception that were retained for days, weeks or months in the uterus

Closed cervical os

Large anechoic sac consistent with an anembryonic gestation

Serial β-hCG assays
Septic 

Pelvic infection and sepsis syndrome

Seen in 1-2% of women with threatened or incomplete miscarriage

questions.text: Which among the following parameters are increased during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Heart rate increases during pregnancy.

Parameters increasing in pregnancy:

  • Cardiac output
  • Stroke volume
  • Heart rate

Parameters decreasing in pregnancy:

  • Peripheral vascular resistance (due to smooth muscle relaxation by progesterone)
  • Both diastolic BP and systolic BP (decrease in DBP > SBP)
  • Serum colloid osmotic pressure
  • Artery venous O2 gradient
 

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: The subdermal implant Jadelle contains _____.
questions.solution:
The subdermal implant Jadelle/ Norplant II contains 2 rods with 70 mg levonorgestrel each. The daily release of hormones is 50 mcg and provides contraception for 3–5 years.

Norplant I  contains six Silastic capsules- has been withdrawn and replaced by a single rod implant.

The implants suppress ovulation in 50% but the main action is suppressing endometrium.

Insertion: The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days of insertion.

Implanon—Amenorrhoea is common at the end of 1 year. Acne is reduced and no osteoporosis.

Advantages of implants:

  • They are long-acting with sustained effect—compliance is good
  • Coital-independent with no ‘nuisance’ of daily oral or frequent injections
  • Pregnancy rate—varies between 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman years

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding, irregular cycles, amenorrhoea occur as with other progestogenic contraceptives.
  • Ectopic pregnancy is reported in 1.3%
  • Local infection may occur
  • Requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules, which are however minor surgical procedures
  • The implants are expensive and cost Rupee 10,000

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: You are an intern and have been assigned the task to calculate the bishop score of a patient. On per vaginal examination, the fetal head is at -2 station and the cervix is 3cm dilated. What score will you record for head-station and cervical dilatation respectively:
questions.solution:
According to Bishop’s score, a score of 1 and 2 will be assigned for the fetal head station and cervical dilation respectively

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman with postpartum hemorrhage has a shock index value of 0.7. What does this value indicate?

choices.text: She has suffered massive blood loss
She has a normal shock index

questions.solution:
Shock index value of 0.7 lies in the normal range.

Shock index is known as Hemodynamic Stability Indicator. Shock index = Heart Rate/systolic Blood Pressure.

  • Normal value of Shock index: 0.5–0.7. Values falling in this range have the lowest likelihood of admission and inpatient mortality.
  • If it becomes 0.9–1.1, it indicates massive blood loss and need for intensive resuscitation.

Clinically, mean blood pressure can best represent tissue perfusion status. Diastolic blood pressure of a critical patient will decrease earlier than systolic blood pressure and mean blood pressure can be an accurate predictor for disease severity. Hence, Modified Shock Index (Heart Rate/Mean Arterial Pressure) is a better indicator to predict the mortality in shock.

questions.text: The frequency of transducer shown in the image is _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows a transvaginal transducer which has a frequency of 5-10 MegaHertz. 
 

Ultrasound refers to sound waves travelling at a frequency above 20,000 hertz.

Vagina transducer of 5-10 Mega Hertz can be used (higher frequency yield better image with minimal penetration) in the first trimester.

Abdominal Transducer of 4-6 Mega Hertz is used (lower frequency penetrates better) in the first and second trimester.

In the third trimester, a lower frequency 2-5 MHz transducer is needed for tissue penetration-particularly in obese patients.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2P1, is informed after her first-trimester scan that the fetus has open spina bifida. At 30 weeks of gestation, her USG scan would most likely report:
questions.solution:
Spina bifida is one of the causes of polyhydramnios. Polyhydramnios is diagnosed when the single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) is greater than 8 cm. 

Open spina bifida causes increased transudation from the meninges, leading to increasing amounts of amniotic fluid production i.e. polyhydramnios.

Polyhydramnios is diagnosed when :

  • Amniotic fluid index (AFI) is greater than 24cm
  • Single deepest vertical pocket  (DVP) is greater than 8cm
  • Amniotic fluid volume is greater than 2L

Other options :

Option A: AFI=4 cm implies oligohydramnios (AFI< 5 cm or DVP< 2cm)

Option B: DVP=2 cm implies oligohydramnios

Option C: AFI = 10 cm implies normal AFI (5-25 cm)

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal
  • Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)
  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • NSAIDs
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Overt diabetes
  • Gestational diabetes
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Liver failure

Fetal
  • Fetal anomalies
  • Renal agenesis
  • Urethral defects
    • Posterior valve
    • Obstructive uropathy

 
  • Multiple gestation
  • Neural tube defects
  • Abdominal wall defects
  • Cleft palate
  • Neck masses
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Aneuploidy
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • TTTS

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: Which of the following statements about endometriosis is false?

choices.text: The most common site of endometriosis is the fallopian tube
The most common symptom of endometriosis is dysmenorrhea
Danazol is used in the treatment of endometriosis

questions.solution:
The most common site of endometriosis is the ovary. Endometriosis of ovary is called endometrioma.

The most common sites of occurrence: Ovary> Pouch of Douglas> Uterosacral ligament> Broad ligament >Fallopian tube.

Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the uterus. 
  • It is a proliferative hormonal dependent disease of the childbearing period.
  • Most common age group: 30-40 years

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management 

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDs DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember for drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analogue
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D:Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P-Progesterone

Surgical management

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 30 year old primigravida with heart disease presents at term for safe confinement. Which among the following statements is false regarding her management?

choices.text: Cut short second stage of labour using ventouse
Antibiotic prophylaxis if she is categorised as high risk only
Puerperal tubal sterilization is done immediately after vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
Puerperal tubal sterilization is delayed for several days in a case with heart disease in order to ensure that the mother has stabilized hemodynamically, is afebrile, not anaemic, and ambulating normally before proceeding with the procedure.

Ergometrine or methyl ergometrine is contraindicated in organic heart disease. Therefore, to control bleeding, oxytocin can be given.

Management

First stage

  • Lateral recumbent position
  • Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
  • Analgesia by epidural
  • Fluids should not be infused more than 75 ml/h
  • Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labour and 48 h after delivery
  • Central venous pressure monitoring

Second stage

  • No maternal pushing
  • Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anaesthsia
  • The benefit of avoiding haemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, haemorrhage and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery.
  • Withhold IV ergometrine with the delivery of anterior shoulder

Third stage

  • Oxytocin by infusion
  • IV frusemide if needed

questions.text: You are charting the partograph of a 24-year-old woman in the labor ward. The graph crosses to the right of the action line. Which zone of the partograph will you find yourself in?
questions.solution:
Once the graph crosses to the right of the action line, you enter the red zone.

WHO Simplified Partograph-this simplified partograph is color-coded :

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is colored green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is colored red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labor.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is colored amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: The following finding is associated with:
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a Couvelaire uterus, observed in severe type of concealed abruptio placentae.

Couvelaire uterus:

  • It is also known as uteroplacental apoplexy.
  • It is observed in severe type of concealed abruption placentae.
  • There is massive intravasation of blood into uterine musculature up to serosa coat, giving it a dark port wine colour.
  • It can be diagnosed only by laparotomy.
  • The presence of Couvelaire uterus observed in CS per se is not an indication for hysterectomy,unless there is uterine atony.

questions.text: Dangerous placenta previa is a variation of :
questions.solution:
Dangerous placenta previa is a variation of type II placenta previa(option b). It is the name given to the type-II posterior placenta previa.

It is so called :

  • Because of the curved birth canal, the major thickness of the placenta (about 2.5cm) overlies the sacral promontory, thereby diminishing the anteroposterior diameter of the inlet and prevents the engagement of the presenting part. This hinders effective compression of the separated placenta to stop bleeding.
  • The placenta is more likely to be compressed if vaginal delivery is allowed.
  • More chance of cord compression or cord prolapse.

The last two may produce fetal anoxia or even death.

questions.text: A primi presented to the hospital in active labor. She gives a history of being HIV positive and is on antiretroviral therapy for the past 2 weeks. She delivers a healthy male baby of 2.6kg. According to the NACO guidelines, at what dose and duration nevirapine has to be given to the infant?
questions.solution:
Nevirapine prophylaxis has to be given for a minimum period of 12 weeks at a dose of 15mg OD, as the mother has taken ART for less than 4 weeks in the antenatal period and the infant is to be breastfed.

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement with respect to the pre-embryonic developmental processes?
questions.solution:
Fertilized ovum implants in the uterine cavity by 6–10 days (after fertilization) in the blastocyst stage.

Other options:

On day 1, fertilization between the ovum and the sperm takes place in the ampulla to form a zygote.

Till day 3, cleavage occurs, to produce a morula.

On day 5, zona hatching takes places to release the blastocyst from the zona pellucida.

 

 

Related Pearl: Timeline of Various Events Occurring during the Pre-embryonic Phase Development (1st two weeks)

Time after Fertilization

Event

< 24 hrs

Zygote is formed; cleavage begins immediately

2–3 days

5–8 cell stage

3–4 days

Stage of compaction and formation of morula with 16 cells

4–5 days

Formation of blastocyst

5–6 days

Zona pellucida disappears

6–7 days

Implantation of the blastocyst

9 days

Bilaminar disc formation

12 days

Formation of extraembryonic mesoderm

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility and underwent an endometrial biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the secretory phase of the endometrium.

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:

 Features in secretory phase/ luteal phase:

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day of the menstrual cycle and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • The epithelium shows subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity).
  • Characteristic corkscrew-shaped glands and edematous stroma.

The image below shows secretory endometrium

 

 Features in proliferative phase/ follicular phase:

  • It begins when the regeneration of menstruating endometrium is complete and lasts until the 14th day of the menstrual cycle.
  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
  • The basal layer of the endometrium and functional layer become more defined.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiraled and extend through the endometrium.

The image below shows proliferative endometrium

 

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with irregular periods. Her ultrasound scan revealed the finding shown in the image. This is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound shows multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern, which is a feature of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD).

Other USG Criteria: 

  • Increased ovarian stroma 
  • 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm arranged in a necklace pattern
  • Ovarian volume >10 ml
  • Single ovary meeting these criteria is enough to diagnose PCOD.

Necklace appearance of right ovary on USG in PCOD:

questions.text: Identify the image shown below:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a chocolate cyst of the ovary. 

Chocolate cysts of the ovaries represent the most important manifestation of endometriosis. Ovaries are frequently involved bilaterally. It is lined by columnar epithelium. 

Beneath the epithelium, large cells with brown cytoplasm called pseudoxanthoma cells are present. These are large macrophages or scavenger cells and their brown coloration is due to ingested blood pigments such as  ­haemosiderin. They are polyhe­dral in shape and resemble lutein cells. 

Chocolate cyst of ovary:

questions.text: Which among the following is an etiological factor for post term pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly is an etiological factor for post term pregnancy.

Maternal stress, nicotine, and infection are related to preterm labour and not post-term labour.

Etiology of post-term pregnancy

  • Wrong dates
  • Heredity
  • Primiparity
  • Previous prolonged pregnancy
  • Sedentary habits
  • Elderly multipara
  • Anencephaly
  • Placental sulphatase deficiency

questions.text: Mcafee and Johnson's  management in case of placenta previa advocates termination of pregnancy at :

choices.text: Immediate termination irrespective of gestational age

questions.solution:
Mcafee and Johnson's expectant management in case of placenta previa advocates termination of pregnancy at 37 weeks.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. 

Prerequisites 

  • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required 
  • Facilities for cesarean section should be available 24 h. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  • Mother in good health(Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%) 
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding 
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG) 

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 wk

         Betamethasone 12mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or

         Dexamethasone 6mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses

  • Bedrest 
  • Hb, Blood grouping and urine for protein 
  • Inspection of vulval pads, fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics 
  • Rh Immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.text: Consider the image given below. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Can lead to acardiac perfused twin
The recipient twin dies of heart failure

questions.solution:
In twin reversal arterial perfusion (TRAP), the donor twin dies of high output heart failure, and the recipient twin lacks a heart (acardius)

Salient features of TRAP: 

  • Large artery-artery anastomosis in the early trimester is followed by large vein-vein anastomosis.
  • In TRAP, blood flow is in 4 vessels (twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome, twin anemia–polycythemia sequence blood flow is 2 vessel pathology).
  • The recipient twin receives deoxygenated blood containing low oxygen; this oxygen is utilized by the lower half of the recipient twin hence heart and upper body are poorly developed.
  • Developmental abnormality in the recipient twin:
a) Failure of head growth - - Termed as acardius acephalous

b) Partially developed head with identifiable limbs- 

 - Acardius myelacephalus

c) No identifiable structures-

 - Acardius amorphous
  • In TRAP, the donor twin is more prone to congestive heart failure.
  • Prognosis of TRAP depends on donor twin.

questions.text: The engaging diameter of the fetal skull in brow presentation is _____.
questions.solution:
The engaging diameter of the fetal skull in brow presentation is mento-vertical.

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a bulge protruding from the vagina that increases in size on coughing and sneezing. She delivered her first baby six weeks back. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of pelvic organ prolapse. Ring pessaries are the preferred management in the case of prolapse in the postnatal period.

Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of the supports of the uterus. The patient may present with a feeling of a bulge protruding through the vaginal opening. Prolapse is aggravated by straining so the bulge increases on sneezing and coughing. It reduces on lying down, or by manual reduction. It may be accompanied by micturition disturbances like difficulty in initiating micturition or frequency of micturition. Rectal symptoms and coital difficulties can be present depending on the degree of prolapse.

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for 3-4 months, with abdominal exercises, massage, and perineal exercises.  Young women rapidly improve if appropriate conservative methods are employed. If surgery is performed within 6 months of delivery, there is a high chance of recurrence of the prolapse.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in the puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months.

Option A: Fothergill's repair also known as Manchester's operation is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.  

Option B: Le Forte's repair: This is preferred only in elderly women with advanced prolapse, or those unfit for surgery. Women wanting an active sexual life are poor candidates for this procedure as it creates an adhesive area in the midline. It may also lead to stress incontinence.

Option D: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl comes for treatment of hirsutism. She has irregular periods. She is obese and has facial acne as well. Androstenedione and testosterone levels are elevated. LH levels are raised and FSH is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the condition?

LH- Luteinizing hormone 

FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone

OCP- Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of hirsutism, irregular periods, acne, and obesity with elevated androgens, normal FSH, and raised LH are suggestive of polycystic ovary disease (PCOD). In PCOD, the drug used for hirsutism and acne is OCPs with cyproterone acetate. Cyproterone has an anti-androgenic effect.

Management of PCOD is individualized. Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are the first-line therapy for PCOD. In a woman who is not planning for pregnancy, the management mainly involves treatment of irregular periods and hirsutism. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. Hirsutism and acne are managed with OCP with cyproterone acetate and topical agents such as eflornithine, clindamycin lotion 1%, erythromycin gel 2%, and isoretinoin. 

Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin and acarbose. Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling (LOD)in resistant cases and bariatric surgery in morbidly obese patients.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)/ Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD): It is also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome.

It is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states.

Important clinical features of PCOS are:

  • Menstrual abnormalities (70%) - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, or dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Dysmenorrhoea is absent.
  • Obesity
  • Hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance
  • Infertility

Rotterdam criterion is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Oligo/amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries (USG findings)

Hormone profile in PCOS:

Increased levels Normal levels Decreased level
  1. Oestrone/E2 level
  2. Serum LH 
  3. LH: FSH ratio 
  4. Testosterone 
  5. Epi-androstenedione
  6. Fasting insulin
  7. Triglycerides

Serum FSH 
  1. SHBG level 
  2. Fasting glucose/ insulin ratio < 4.5

Investigations:

  1. Hormonal studies
  2. USG is diagnostic of PCOS- It shows enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles in the periphery. It also rules out other pathologies like ovarian tumors, endometrial hyperplasia, etc.
  3. Laparoscopy (therapeutic). It reveals bilateral enlarged ovarian cysts.

Ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery.

Note:

PCOS in association with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease presenting in reproductive age group is known as "X syndrome".

HAIR-AN syndrome in patients with PCOS is characterized by HyperAndrogenism, Insulin Resistance and Acanthosis Nigricans.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient with a known case of rheumatic heart disease is in her first trimester. She has complaints of chest pain and syncope. Cardiac failure in pregnancy is most likely to occur in which of the following time period?
questions.solution:
Cardiac failure in pregnancy is most likely to occur during the immediate postpartum period.

Cardiac failure during pregnancy can occur mostly following delivery. It can also occur during labor and at around 30 weeks.

Advancing age, cardiac arrhythmias, history of previous heart failure, and other pregnancy risk factors such as anemia, infection, hypertension, and multiple pregnancies can cause cardiac failure. 

Features include breathlessness, syncope, chest pain, and nocturnal cough. Chest murmurs, cardiac enlargement, and arrhythmia may be present. Chest radiography reveals an enlarged heart, increased pulmonary markings, and enlargement of pulmonary veins.

Maternal cardiac risk predictors are [Mnemonic: NOPE]

N-NYHA class >2

O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2 OR Aortic valve area <1.5 cm2,   peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg.

P-Prior cardiac events before pregnancy

E-Ejection fraction <40%

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents to the hospital with complaints of vaginal bleeding and mild abdominal pain. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. Pelvic examination reveals a 10-12 week, non-tender uterus. Urine hCG is positive. A pelvic ultrasonogram is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

LMP-last menstrual period 

hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasonogram showing characteristic snow storm appearance are suggestive of a complete hydatiform mole. Suction curettage will be the appropriate management for this patient.

The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces but without a fetus and amnionic sac. Combined with a raised hCG and a uterus larger than the date of pregnancy, the diagnosis of a complete hydatidiform mole is made.

Management of a complete mole is by suction curettage, which effectively removes the molar tissue from the patient.

Preoperative cervical dilatation with an osmotic agent is recommended if the cervix is minimally dilated. With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support are important. Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.

Other options:

Option A: Expectant management is not appropriate in the case of the complete mole as patients may develop complications.

Option B: Methotrexate therapy can be used to treat a persistent or metastatic complete mole.

Option D: Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their families.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes for a regular gynecological check-up. Pap smear testing showed HSIL. Therefore, biopsy was done, which showed dysplastic changes in 2/3rd of the epithelial thickness. What is the diagnosis?

HSIL - High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is cervical intraepithelial neoplasia II (CIN II).

CIN is the histopathological description of a partial/full-thickness stratified squamous epithelium replaced by dysplastic cells arranged in a disorderly manner (abnormally altered morphology). However, the basement membrane remains intact, distinguishing it from cervical cancer.

Diagnosis is mainly based on routine screening as most women are asymptomatic (some may complain of postcoital bleeding/discharge or postmenopausal bleeding). Routine screening should start with sexually active (for more than three years) women above 21 years of age and should be repeated every 3-5 years until the age of 65 years.

Pap smear testing is done to identify cervical dysplasia, and the findings are classified according to the Bethesda system of cytology reporting, as follows:

  • Atypical squamous cells: Ascus - atypical cells of undetermined significance and ASC-H - cannot rule out high-grade lesion
  • Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL): includes CIN I
  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL): includes CIN II and CIN III
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

As the presence of an infection can produce false-positive findings, human papillomavirus (HPV) testing is also done along with Pap smear screening. Patients who are found to have HSIL are further subjected to biopsy. This is done by colposcopic study for the visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) for acetowhite areas and taking biopsies of abnormal areas.

CIN, along with multiple sexual partners and infection with HPV strains 16, 18, 31, and 33, is a major predisposing high-risk factor for cervical cancer; thus, the need for routine screening in women.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: A woman with 31 weeks of gestation presents with lower abdominal pain. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals a U shaped cervix. Which of the following will be true in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the U shaped cervix points towards the diagnosis of preterm labour where fetal fibronectin value will be greater than 50ng/ml (or 0.05mg/l).

Shape of the cervix on TVS: Seen in:
T shaped Normal
Y shaped Suspicion of preterm labour
U shaped  Incompetent os, preterm labour

Fibronectin detection in cervicovaginal secretions before membrane rupture is a possible marker for impending preterm labor.

Fetal fibronectin:

  • Fetal fibronectin is a glycoprotein present in high concentrations in maternal blood and in amniotic fluid.
  • It aids in intercellular adhesion during implantation and in the maintenance of placental adherence to uterine decidua.
  • The value of fetal fibronectin predictive of preterm labour is >50 ng/ml.
  • Fetal fibronectin is measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and values exceeding 50 ng/mL are considered positive.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the gynecologist with complaints of severe itching in the vulva and foul-smelling, thin, green-colored vaginal discharge. Examination of the cervix shows the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image depicting colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix is seen in trichomoniasis.

Trichomoniasis is caused by the organism Trichomonas vaginalis. It characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. 

In women, diagnosis is usually confirmed by examination of wet mount microscopy and direct visualization. However, a culture, usually in Feinberg–Whittington medium, gives the most reliable results. 

Standard treatment is with a single oral dose of 2 grams of metronidazole or 2 grams of tinidazole. Metronidazole 500 mg given orally for seven days is also effective.

Colpitis Macularis or Strawberry Cervix(image below) appearance results from microscopic, punctate hemorrhages of the cervix. 

Other options:

Option 1: Chlamydial cervicitis is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Patients present with mucopurulent discharge or endocervical secretions, urethritis, dysuria, etc. On examination, the cervix may appear edematous and hyperemic.

The image below shows an inflamed cervix from chlamydia infection characterized by mucopurulent cervical discharge and erythema.

Option 3: Gonorrhea is a suppurative bacterial infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.The patient usually presents with profuse, odorless, non-irritant, white, or yellow vaginal discharge. They also have dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, and intermenstrual bleeding. The patient might also present with proctitis.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale, a genital ulcer is caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. It is also known as donovanosis. It presents as painless nodules that develop into ulcerative lesions. The ulcer is highly vascular with a beefy red appearance and subcutaneous granulomas extend to form pseudobuboes.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A G2P1 woman has presented to the hospital in active labor. You conduct the delivery and now proceed to the active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). Which of the following is  recommended in active management of the third stage of labor according to WHO:

choices.text: Early cord clamping to prevent blood loss
Sustained uterine massage to prevent atony

questions.solution:
Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment is recommended according to the WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). 

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who was previously diagnosed with an ovarian fibroma presents with gradually progressive abdominal distension, cough, breathlessness, and pleuritic chest pain on the right side. On examination, the abdomen is distended, and fluid thrill is present. Chest x-ray shows a right-sided pleural effusion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the triad of benign ovarian fibroma, right-sided pleural effusion, and ascites are suggestive of Meigs syndrome.

The following triad of features favors the diagnosis:

  • Gradual progressive distension of abdomen, positive fluid thrill – points towards ascites.
  • Cough on lying to the right side, breathlessness, chest pain on the right side, chest X-ray – point towards right-sided pleural effusion.
  • Diagnosis of ovarian fibroma– benign ovarian tumor.

Meigs syndrome is mostly caused by ovarian fibroma. CA-125 levels may also be elevated. As it is a diagnosis of exclusion, a workup should be done to rule out malignancy. Exploratory laparotomy with surgical staging is the treatment of choice. Conservative surgery (salpingo-oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

Other options: 

Option B: Pseudo-Meigs syndrome, which presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign tumors of the ovary (other than fibromas). Other features may include fibroids/leiomyoma, secondary metastatic tumors to the ovary, Brenners tumors, and benign ovarian cysts (such as struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, and teratomas).

Option C: Pseudo-pseudo Meigs syndrome is a manifestation of SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) defined by ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated CA-125 levels.

Option D: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome occurs as a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhea. It is characterized by the inflammation of the peritoneum and the tissues surrounding the liver (perihepatitis). Symptoms include sudden onset of severe pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, fever, chills, and malaise.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes with a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability. The ultrasound image of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability along with ultrasound findings of double decidual sign points to the diagnosis of normal pregnancy.

This sign can be seen in first-trimester transvaginal sonograms. In the image, the empty head red arrow points to the concentric double rings that are - the outer decidua parietalis and the inner decidua capsularis. The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac. The presence of the yolk sac confirms the intrauterine location of the pregnancy. It usually appears by the 5th week.

Another indicator of early intrauterine pregnancy is the intradecidual sign. It is seen as an anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim.

Cardiac motion is usually seen after the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: You are a resident assisting a vaginal delivery. Because the baby goes into distress, the second stage of labor is shortened with the use of the instrument shown below. Where will you place the cup of the instrument?

choices.text: On the mother's abdomen, within a 2-cm radius of the umbilicus
On a point 3 cm from the anterior fontanelle and 6 cm from posterior fontanelle of the fetal head
At the extension point on the fetal head
On the sagittal suture on the fetal head

questions.solution:
The given image shows a vacuum delivery system, and during vaccum-assisted delivery, the suction cup is placed on the fetal scalp on the sagittal suture.

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp.

The instrument consists of the following components:

  • Suction cup
  • Vacuum generator
  • Traction tubing device

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput, called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel.

Once the cup is placed over the flexion point, the ventouse extraction is started by creating a vacuum pressure of 0.2 kg/cm2. This takes about 2 minutes. The pressure is then gradually increased up to an effective vacuum pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 at the rate of 0.1 kg/cm2 per minute; traction is then applied.

Traction:

  • Traction is applied at a right angle to the cup and should be synchronous to the uterine contractions.
  • Between the uterine contractions, the traction is released.
  • Traction is made using one hand along the axis of the birth canal, while the fingers of the other hand are placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation, and advancement of the head.

Traction should be abandoned if

  • There is no decent of the presenting part with each pull
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed more than 30 minutes. Once the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve and the cup is then detached.

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.solution:

Uterus, fallopian tube, cervix, and upper vaginal wall arise from the paramesonephric duct.

questions.text: The maneuver shown in the image is used in ______.

choices.text: Delivery of after coming head in breech presentation
Delivery of extended arms in breech presentation
Delivery of after coming head in breech when back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis pubis

questions.solution:
The maneuver shown in the image is the Lovset's maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

Modified Prague’s maneuver is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand. 

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre :

Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion in case of shoulder dystocia.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Tobacco juice colored amniotic fluid is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Tobacco juice (brown) colored amniotic fluid is seen in intrauterine death.

The dark color is due to frequent presence of old HbA.

The color of amniotic fluid can vary in different conditions. The normal color of amniotic fluid is usually clear or tinted yellow. Golden color amniotic fluid is seen in Rh incompatibility where there is excess hemolysis of fetal RBCs and there is excess bilirubin.

Color  Conditions
Pale straw Near term due to exfoliated lanugo hairs, exfoliated cells from fetal skin
Green Meconium/listeria infection
Golden yellow Rh incompatibility
Saffron Post maturity
Dark  haemorrhage
Brown (Tobacco juice) Intrauterine death

questions.text: A young woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea, presents with complaints of heavy vaginal bleeding. On examination, an open cervical os with tissue protruding is seen. Ultrasonography reveals echogenic material in the uterine cavity, no adnexal masses, no free fluid, and no viable pregnancy. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient has an incomplete abortion and the most appropriate management would be to evacuate the contents of the uterus with dilatation and curettage.

The patient can present with complaints of the expulsion of fleshy mass per vagina, continuous vaginal bleeding, and abdominal cramps. Internal examination reveals open cervical os, and products of conception protruding out of the cervix. Ultrasonography reveals echogenic material (retained products of conception) within the cavity and no viable pregnancy. There are no adnexal masses, and no free fluid found on ultrasonography, ruling out ectopic pregnancy. All this confirms the diagnosis of incomplete abortion. 

Incomplete abortion can be managed surgically, or medically. The surgical method is by dilatation and curettage, it has the least failure rate and gives a quick resolution. For medical management of incomplete abortion at <13 weeks gestation, use of 600 μg misoprostol administered orally or use of 400 μg misoprostol administered sublingually, is recommended.

Note- For medical management of incomplete miscarriage, the use of 400–800 μg vaginal misoprostol has been removed in the updated recommendation from the WHO 2012 Safe abortion guidance (6).
