Seen in 1-2% of women with threatened or incomplete miscarriage

  -

 

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: If division occurs in an implanted blastocyst, it will give rise to:
questions.solution:
If the division occurs in an implanted blastocyst, i.e. after the 8th day, it will give rise to monochorionic monoamniotic twins.

questions.text: A pap smear was done on a 39-year-old woman as a part of a routine health checkup. The cytology picture is shown below. The cell marked A in the smear is _______.
questions.solution:
The cell marked A in the smear is a superficial cell which is an estrogen-dominant cell. These are acidophilic (pink) cells with a pyknotic nucleus seen predominantly in the first half of the menstrual cycle.

  • Intermediate cells: Progesterone dominant cells which are basophilic (blue or green) with distinct margins and nuclei bigger than that of superficial cells. These are seen in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy.
  • Basal and parabasal cells are seen when no hormone predominates. These are basophilic cells with no distinct outlines and a much larger nucleus. Seen in menopause and the postpartum period.
  • Human papilloma infected cells: Shows koilocytes. These cells have hyperchromatic enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halo.

The cytology image of a normal Pap smear is shown below.

The koilocytes(right side) compared to normal Pap smear(left side).

questions.text: A 30 year old pregnant lady with 32 weeks of gestation presents with thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning. Which of the following can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of monilial vaginitis/ vaginal candidiasis.

The drug of choice for monilial vaginitis is Fluconazole. A single dose of fluconazole 150 mg has been found to be very effective.

Local intravaginal application of antifungal agents such as imidazole, miconazole, clotrimazole, butoconazole or ter­conazole vaginal pessaries or creams used for 3–6 days is also very effective.

Risk Factors For candidal infection include:

  • Promiscuity
  • Immunosuppression
  • HIV
  • Pregnancy
  • Steroid therapy
  • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Diabe­tes mellitus
  • Poor personal hygiene and
  • Obesity

questions.text: The finding shown in the image is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows perihepatic adhesion which is seen in pelvic inflammatory disease.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is a perihepatitis which occurs in the setting of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It occurs in approximately 10 percent of women with acute PID.

Gonococcal salpingits/ chlamydial infection → transperitoneal/ vascular spread→ inflammation of the liver capsule and peritoneal surfaces of the anterior right upper quadrant.

Characterized by right upper quadrant abdominal pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder.

The image given represents the violin-string adhesions of chronic Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

questions.text: A 26 year old G2P1 woman is infected by treponema pallidum in the 10th week of her pregnancy. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: There is an increased risk of postterm pregnancy
Newborn will present with hutchinson triad
The placenta will be enlarged and pale
There  is an increased risk of macrosomia

questions.solution:
The enlarged and pale placenta is due to infection by treponema pallidum in pregnancy.

Other clinical manifestations and complications include:

  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Preterm birth
  • Stillbirth
  • Non-immune hydrops 
  • intrauterine growth restriction 
  • Perinatal death

 Hutchinson triad is not seen in a newborn, but a late sign of congenital syphilis seen after 2yrs.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman with a history of abortion 3 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea and a desire for pregnancy. Her hysterosalpingography revealed multiple filling defects. Her hysteroscopy is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is false?

D&C- Dilatation and curettage

choices.text: It occurs due to endometrial damage
Risk of this condition is least when D&C is done for postpartum hemorrhage
It can cause recurrent abortions due to inadequate placentation

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and hysteroscopy is suggestive of Asherman syndrome and the risk of developing Asherman syndrome is high if dilatation and curettage (D&C) are done in the postpartum period.

Asherman syndrome is a spectrum of scarring that includes filmy adhesions, dense bands, or complete obliteration of the uterine cavity. It occurs as a result of damage to the endometrium and the risk of this condition increases in pregnancy-related curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion complicated by infection. Damage may also result from other uterine surgery and infection associated with an intrauterine device.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients can develop amenorrhea (in less severe cases), hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss due to inadequate placentation.

Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy. Treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis. It improves fertility rates and relieves symptomatic hematometra.

questions.text: Carcinoma endometrium with metastasis to para aortic lymph nodes belongs to ______ stage.
questions.solution:
Carcinoma endometrium with metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes with or without metastasis to pelvic lymph nodes belongs to stage 3 C2.

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with fever with chills and abdominal pain 2 days after vaginal delivery. She also has foul-smelling lochia. Parametrial tenderness is elicited on abdominal and bimanual examination. Her WBC count was 25000/ microlitre. Which among the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Anaerobic streptococcus is the predominant pathogen involved
Risk is more with vaginal delivery when compared with caesarian section
Placental site is involved most commonly following vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of puerperal sepsis. The risk of developing puerperal sepsis is more with a caesarian section when compared with vaginal delivery.

  • The most common route of spread of puerperal sepsis is direct spread.
  • The most common site of puerperal infection is the placental site in vaginal delivery and uterine incision in a cesarean section. (Option D)
  • The most common manifestation of puerperal infection is Endometritis. (Option C)
  • The most common cause of puerperal sepsis is Streptococcus. (Option A)
  • The most important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis is the route of delivery (Cesarean > Vaginal). (Option B)
  • The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following a cesarean section is administrating a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery. None of the other steps with respect to surgical closure of the abdomen have proven benefit in decreasing puerperal infection.

questions.text: A healthy woman with a normal pregnancy is being evaluated during her antenatal visit. Which of the following is likely to be seen in her thyroid profile?
questions.solution:
Free T3 (triiodothyronine), free T4 (thyroxine), and TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) levels remain normal during pregnancy. Therefore, normal free T3 levels are likely to be seen in the thyroid profile of a healthy woman with normal pregnancy.

Endocrine glands show physiological changes during pregnancy to meet the extra demands of the growing fetus. Maternal total T4 and T3 levels are increased during the early period of gestation due to stimulation of the thyroid gland by hCG (α-subunit of hCG is similar to TSH). TSH levels in the first trimester decline slightly (but remain in the normal range). The level of TSH is normal during the second and third trimesters.

The physiologically important free T4 and free T3 levels are unchanged due to the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG). Hence, pregnant women remain euthyroid. 

The hormonal changes during pregnancy are as follows:

Increased Decreased Unchanged

Growth Hormone

Insulin (due to insulin resistance)

Prolactin

Total T3, T4

Aldosterone

Testosterone, Androstenedione, and cortisol

LH (Luteinizing hormone)

FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone)

DHEAS (Di-hydro epiandrosterone)

Free T3, T4

TSH

ADH (Anti-  diuretic hormone)
 
Plasma insulin level is increased in pregnancy due to a number of hormones that increase insulin resistance including:
  • Human placental lactogen 
  • Progesterone and estrogen
  • Placental growth hormone 
  • Cortisol
  • Prolactin

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A 28 year old female on combined oral contraceptives presents to the clinic on 24th day of her menstrual cycle as she had forgotten to take tablets on the 22nd and 23rd day. What would be your advice for her regarding contraception?

choices.text: Take two pills at the scheduled time

questions.solution:
The last 7 pills in the 28 pill pack are non-hormonal (iron tablets). She can discard the missed pills and continue taking the rest of the pills as usual. 

A woman can start using combined oral contraceptives anytime if it is reasonably certain that she's not pregnant. If she starts taking the pills within 5 days of the start of her menstrual period, she can just continue to take one pill a day and there's no need for backup contraception. If she starts taking pills 5 days after the onset of her menstrual period, then she should use a backup contraceptive (barrier contraception) for the first 7 days.

 

Missed pills Management

Missed 1 or 2 pills

 

 Take the missed pill as soon as possible, resume schedule, no backup method necessary

Missed 2 pills

  • In weeks 1 or 2: take 2 pills daily for 2 days then finish the pack, backup is not needed but advised for 7 days

  • In week 3: Start a new pack. Backup for 7 days.
Missed >3 pills
  • Start a new pack
  • Backup contraception for the next 7 days

 

If any non-hormonal pills were missed, she can discard the remaining pills. Start the new pack of oral contraceptives and continue taking as usual.

If she vomits within 2 hours of taking a pill, another pill from the pack should be taken as soon as possible. After that, continue taking the pills as scheduled. If the vomiting or diarrhoea persists for >2 days, follow the instructions for 1 or 2 missed pills as mentioned above.

The contraceptive method should be discontinued and changed in the following situations:

  • Unexplained or prolonged heavy vaginal bleeding that suggests an underlying condition not related to the method
  • Starting anticonvulsant medication or treatment with rifampicin
  • Migraines
  • Non-ambulatory conditions lasting for >1 week like major surgery, leg in a cast, etc. Combined oral contraceptives can be restarted 2 weeks after ambulation.
  • Suspected heart or liver disease, hypertension, deep vein thrombosis, stroke, breast cancer, diabetes, or gall bladder disease 

 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Paalman and McElin's criteria is used for the diagnosis of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Paalman and McElin's criteria is used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy.

Paalman and McElin's criteria is as follows:

  • Soft enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea without cramping pain
  • Products of conception entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os

Other options:

Option A: Ovarian pregnancy- Spiegelberg’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

Option B: Abdominal pregnancy- Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement about the instrument given below?

choices.text: It measures the uterine cavity and the cervical length
It differentiates between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
It is used to diagnose cervical stenosis

questions.solution:
The given instrument is Simpson’s uterine sound. It is not used to retract the vagina for cervical examination. This is done using Sim's speculum.

The instrument is held like a pencil with the thumb and the first 2 fingers and introduced into the uterine cavity by keeping it in the midline and ensuring it is not forced.

The uses are given as follows:

  • To measure uterine cavity and cervical length
  • To diagnose cervical stenosis
  • To sound a polyp, IUCD or uterine septum
  • To break adhesions
  • To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is safe during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Rabies vaccine is safe during pregnancy.

It is a killed vaccine and can be given as usual.

  • Killed vaccines are safe in pregnancy.
  • Live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy. (MMR,BCG, Varicella)

Note:

  • Only tetanus toxoid is given in pregnancy.
  • Cholera vaccine may be given during epidemics.
  • Hepatitis A and B vaccines are safe.

Yellow fever vaccine is a live vaccine. But in areas where YF is endemic, or during outbreaks, pregnant women and nursing mothers should be counselled on the potential benefits and risks of vaccination. Vaccination is recommended, if indicated, for pregnant or breastfeeding women travelling to endemic areas when such travel cannot be avoided or postponed.

questions.text: The action depicted in the following image is used to induce labour.  What is the reflex elicited in the process?
questions.solution:
Stripping of membranes is being depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex.

Foetal ejection reflex (Ferguson reflex) is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity.

Its exact mechanism is not clear, and release of oxytocin from maternal pituitary has been suggested but not proven.

It is seen in stripping/sweeping and artificial rupture of membranes both of which are methods of induction of labour. (Stripping/Sweeping: Digital separation of chorioamniotic membranes from the wall of cervix & lower uterine segment).It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite (PGFM), also known as dinoprost.

questions.text: The image depicts the quantitative test for fetomaternal hemorrhage. What inference can be derived from this test?

choices.text: Fetal RBCs are washed out and maternal RBCs are red
Maternal RBCs are washed out and fetal RBCs are red
Both maternal and fetal RBCs are washed out and few immature RBCs are alone red
Both maternal and fetal RBCs are red and few immature RBCs are washed out

questions.solution:
The test shown is the Kleihauer-Betke test. The test shows that the maternal RBCs are washed out and fetal RBCs are red. This is because the fetal RBCs are resistant to acid digestion.

Principle of this test is that the fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A in the maternal erythrocytes.

Kleihauer–Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation. The reagent used for the Kleihauer–Betke test is citric acid. It is also known as the acid elution test.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as ghosts. These fetal cells are counted per 50 low-power fields. If there are 80 fetal erythrocytes in 50 low-power fields in maternal peripheral blood films, it represents a transplacental hemorrhage to the extent of 4 mL of fetal blood. 10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

Fetomaternal hemorrhage can also be quantified using flow cytometry to measure red cell size. It is unaffected by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin F or by fetal levels of hemoglobin A. Flow cytometry has been reported to be more sensitive and accurate than the Kleihaeur Betke test.

questions.text: The appearance of the fallopian tube as shown in the image is seen in:
questions.solution:
The given image is of tuberculous salpingitis resembling a tobacco pouch appearance.

Fallopian tube lesion in Tuberculosis:

  • Involvement is 100% and bilateral, secondary to hematogenous spread
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance: Tubes appear dilated with fimbrial end open and pouting
  • External surface: Greyish with tubercles
  • On cut section: Lumen has yellowish-grey caseous matter or serosanguinous fluid (Tuberculous hematosalpinx) and pyosalpinx.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient has completed a family and wanted a sterilization technique which can be surgically reversible. The following method of sterilization was done as shown below.
questions.solution:
The sterilization technique which can be surgically reversible and shown in the image is the Pomeroy technique.

The Pomeroy method is the most popular technique of tubal ligation in which the fallopian tube is identified on each side and brought out through the incision. The middle portion is then formed into a loop, tied at the base and excised. 

It is surgically reversible and has a short hospitalization. 

Other options:

Option A: In Uchida's method, the serosa in the midsegment of the tube is stripped off from the mucosa and then excised. The proximal segment is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimum tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty. 

Option B: The technique of fimbriectomy is irreversible. In this method, fimbria is excised. Thus, it is a permanent method of sterilisation. 

Option D: In Irving's procedure, the mid-portion of the tube is ligated with excision of the intervening portion. The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible method and may require a laparotomy incision.

The below image shows Pomeroy technique

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility and is posted for a hysterosalpingogram. Which of the following is not a contraindication for hysterosalpingography?
questions.solution:
All of the following are contraindications for hysterosalpingography (HSG) except option C. Uterine synechiae is an indication for HSG.

Contraindications for HSG:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding
  • Genital Tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye. 

It is best performed between day 5 and day 10 of the menstrual cycle.

10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal patency
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • Feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L1 woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with pruritus on the palms and soles for 2 weeks. She also had yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL. Alkaline phosphatase levels were elevated, and serum transaminase levels were normal. She also reports that she had similar complaints during the previous pregnancy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease occurring in the 2nd or 3rd trimester. It is characterized by pruritus (worse on palms and soles and at the night) and icterus. It is also known as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum.

Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment, but total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 4 to 5 mg/dL. Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated, but seldom exceed 250 U/L. Total and fasting serum bile acid concentrations are elevated. Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated. Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Management comprises antihistamines, topical emollients, cholestyramine, and ursodeoxycholic acid.

Other options:

Option B: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy manifests mostly in the last trimester of pregnancy with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, epigastric pain, and progressive jaundice. There may be hypertension, protein­uria, and edema. There is moderate to severe liver dysfunction with hypofi­brinogenemia, hypoalbuminemia, hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting times. Serum bilirubin level is usually <10 mg/dL, and serum transaminases are ele­vated but <1000 U/L.

Option C: Acute viral hepatitis is usually asymptomatic. When symptomatic, it presents with nausea, vomiting, and malaise, followed by jaundice. Low-grade fever may be present. Serum bilirubin rises, and transaminase levels vary.

Option D: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is commonly associated with obesity, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia­ syndrome. It is usually asymptomatic with elevated transaminases.

questions.text: You perform Pinard's manoeuvre while conducting a delivery. Which of these other manoeuvres are you least likely to have performed to deliver this baby?
questions.solution:
Pinard's maneuver is used in case of a breech presentation while Wood's maneuver is used in shoulder presentation, thus making Wood's less likely to be performed in this delivery.

Pinard’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

Lovset’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

 

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre is shown in the image. It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre :

Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion in case of shoulder dystocia.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which among the following is a premalignant lesion of the vulva?
questions.solution:
Bowen’s disease is a pre malignant lesion of the vulva.

Premalignant lesions of Vulva:

  • Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)
  • Paget’s disease
  • Lichen Sclerosus
  • Squamous cell hyperplasia
  • Condyloma accuminata
  • Bowen’s disease (erythroplasia of queyrat)

Note: VIN is the most common premalignant lesion of vulva.

Bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis and moniliasis are not premalignant lesions of the vulva.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters correlates with the severity of the malformation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
HbA1c levels correlate with the malformation given in the image, namely, caudal regression sequence/ sacral agenesis.

It is a rare anomaly. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and, to a lesser degree, the lumbar vertebrae, and occurs more frequently in an infant of a diabetic mother than in other infants.

The maternal condition that can give rise to this condition in the baby is pregestational diabetes. HbA1c levels correlate with the malformations. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes. Poorly controlled diabetes, both preconceptionally and in early pregnancy, is thought to cause this malformation.

Other options:

Option B- Folic acid deficiency in pregnancy increases the risk of spina bifida.

Option C- Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis if taken during pregnancy.

Option D- Lithium can cause Ebstein anomaly if taken during pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida had pre-pregnancy BMI of 19 kg/msq. What is the recommended weight gain during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The recommended weight gain in the above case in a woman with normal BMI is 11-16 kg.

Ideally weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy body mass index (BMI) level.

Related Pearl: Recommendation for total weight gain during pregnancy by pre-pregnancy BMI

Category (BMI) Total weight gain range [kg(lb)]
Underweight (<18.5) 12.5 - 18 (28-40 lb)
Normal weight (BMI 18.5-24.9) 11.5 - 16 (25-35 lb)
Overweight (BMI 25-29.9) 7 – 11.5 (15-25 lb)
Obese (BMI more than equal to 30) 5 - 9.1 (11-20 lb)

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 28 weeks of gestation undergoes a 75-g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Her fasting plasma glucose level was 100 mg/dL, 1-hour OGTT is 190 mg/dL, and 2-hour OGTT is 160 mg/dL. Which of the following statements is true about her condition?

choices.text: Her condition causes the highest rates of anomalies in the fetus.
There is increased risk of fetal macrosomia.
Oral hypoglycemic agents are the first-line agents for treatment.

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), and there is an increased risk of fetal macrosomia in gestational diabetes mellitus. Maternal hyperglycemia causes fetal hyperinsulinemia, which leads to increased fetal growth or macrosomia.

All pregnant women are screened at 24–28 weeks for GDM. In India, we follow the one-step method recommended by The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG).

Threshold values for gestational diabetes (75-g OGTT):

Plasma glucose Glucose concentration threshold
Fasting 92 mg/dL
1 hr OGTT 180 mg/dL
2 hr OGTT 153 mg/dL

One or more of these values in a 75-g OGTT should be equaled or exceeded to make a diagnosis of gestational diabetes. In this case, all three values exceed the threshold, so a diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus is made.

Option A: Women with overt diabetes are at a greater risk of developing congenital defects than those with gestational diabetes. Women with overt diabetics are those who are known to have diabetes before pregnancy.

Patients with overt diabetes show superoxide-free radicle production and hyperglycemia-induced gene upregulation since the first trimester. The first trimester is when organogenesis takes place. Hence, overt diabetes patients have a higher risk of developing congenital anomalies. GDM develops during the late second to early third trimester and does not affect organogenesis. 

The following are the laboratory findings that would be suggestive of overt diabetes in a mother:

  • Fasting blood sugar of at least 126 mg/dL
  • A random blood sugar of at least 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c of at least 6.5%

The anomalies seen in an infant of a diabetic mother are cardiac anomalies (most common), neural tube defects, cleft palate, hypospadias, renal problems, etc.

Caudal regression syndrome is the most characteristic anomaly seen in overt diabetes.

Option C: Hyperinsulinemia can cause neonatal hypoglycemia.

Option D: Insulin is the preferred first-line agent in women with gestational diabetes, when target glucose levels cannot be achieved through nutrition and exercise.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female patient complains of hot flushes, inability to concentrate, and sleep disturbances. Which among the following would help in the prediction of her approaching menopause?

choices.text: A rise in inhibin B level
A rise in anti-Mullerian hormone level

questions.solution:
A rise in FSH level helps in the prediction of approaching menopause.

Predictors of approaching menopause are:

  • A fall in the level of inhibin B. This causes a rise in the FSH level 
  • Low ovarian reserve and low antral follicular count are suggested by a fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone. 
  • A rise in FSH and a more than normal LH level 

FSH levels are studied on days 2-5 after the last menstrual period. This helps to identify the premenopausal stage.

Menopause is the permanent cessation of ovarian function, thereby, leading to permanent amenorrhea. It usually occurs between 45 - 50 years, but the average age of menopause is 47 years old and is confirmed after 12 months of amenorrhoea. Some of the features include:

  • Hot flushes which are transient heat sensations occurring in the face and neck and lasting for 2-5 minutes followed by sweating.
  • Insomnia, headache
  • Dyspareunia
  • Irritability, depression, tiredness
  • Lack of concentration and lack of memory

Note: Perimenopause is 3-4 years preceding menopause and is followed by 1 year of amenorrhoea.

questions.text: A child presents with dyspnoea and a chest X-ray is taken. Xray is suggestive of a heart defect as shown below. Which of the following drugs should you suspect his mother to have taken during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The chest Xray is that of a box-shaped heart suggestive of Ebstein's anomaly, seen in children where there is a maternal history of intake of lithium during pregnancy.

Safety Profile of medications in pregnancy as classified by the FDA :

  • Category  A. Strong evidence of safety based on human studies.
  • Category  B. Varying and/or contradictory human and animal data.
  • Category  C. Shown side effects in animal models, or where inadequate animal and human studies are available.
  • Category  D. Shown risk to the human fetus.
  • Category  X. Strong risk of birth defects (ACE-inhibitors like ramipril, lithium, methotrexate, alcohol, valproate, mifepristone, danazol, isotretinoin, radioactive iodine etc

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
